awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Polarimetric Tornado Precursor Signatures
awd_abstract_narration:
Tornadoes are a significant hazard in the United States and while tornado warning times have lengthened over the past few decades, there is still room for improvement.  One of the recent technological advancements in tornado science is the use of dual-polarimetric radar data.  Dual-polarimetric radars transmit signals horizontally and vertically.  Through the combination of those signals, we can infer properties of rain, snow and hail, such as their size and shape.  It has been observed that there are specific polarimetric signals that show up prior to some tornado events.  This research award will investigate those signals to determine why they form and whether they are good candidates to be used as indicators for developing tornadoes.  The societal impact of the project is related to improving tornado warning times and increasing public safety.  The research team is also working with an author to develop a non-fiction book about tornado scientists, targeted at 8 to 11-year-olds, to enhance scientific literacy.

The goal of this project is to develop conceptual models of recurring differential reflectivity signatures in supercells with potential prognostic value for tornadogenesis.  The research team will analyze existing rapid-scanning dual-polarized radar observations in supercells, collect new observations using a novel rapid-scanning dual-polarized mobile radar system, and utilize both sets of observations to develop and refine conceptual models of these differential reflectivity (Zdr) signatures in relation to tornadogenesis.  The researchers will systematically focus on the Zdr column and Zdr arc behavior immediately prior to tornadogenesis, comprehensively documenting and analyzing a sample of 8-10 supercells.  At least five additional tornadic supercells will be sampled using the UMass-Amherst phase-tilt weather radar (PTWR) during field studies during the award.

por.por_cntn:
Our team sought to learn how some storms that produce tornadoes differ from storms that do not produce tornadoes, when viewed using dual-polarized radar. In particular, we focused on two specific features: the ZDR column and the ZDR arc. We hypothesized that these features will change in measurable ways in the five minutes before a tornado forms, and that these changes will not be observed if a tornado does not form (tornadogenesis failure).

Our team used a mobile, dual-polarized rapidly-scanning weather radar (UMass Skyler) to observe thunderstorms that were capable of producing tornadoes. UMass Skyler is different from those used in the past in that it has a combination of both dual-polarized and phased array radar technology. (We expect these two technologies to be combined in the next generation of operational weather radars used across the U.S.) Our team operated UMass Skyler in the field for two seasons and observed 16 nontornadic storms, but additional field work was cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Instead, the team chose to focus on archived data from past field campaigns in which tornadic storms were observed by experimental dual-polarized radars, and on simulating dual-polarized radar data using computing techniques. Along the way, our team tested several automated methods to identify and track ZDR columns and ZDR arcs in storms. One member of our team found, by tracking ZDR columns in archived dual-polarized observations of a tornadic storm, that numerous, small flashes were produced inside the ZDR column, whereas a smaller number of large, more expansive flashes occurred outside the ZDR column. A different team member found that the life span of a ZDR column ranged from 10 to 20 minutes in southeast U.S. storms, with longer-lived ZDR columns being associated with longer-lived storms.

Another member of our team produced synthetic ZDR arcs in a set of computer simulations that reproduced both tornadic and nontornadic supercells. They found that ZDR arc area can be expected to increase in the five minutes before a tornado forms, and that the expansion is greater in tornadic than in storms that experience tornadogenesis failure. However, the usefulness of this technique may be limited by the effects of hail fallout, which tends to decrease the area of the ZDR arc overall.

An additional member of the team tested a new technique to ensure that all the ZDR observations collected by UMass Skyler were well-calibrated. While the technique not successful, it led to an additional project testing the technique on other, current, non-phased array radars.

Lastly, this project contributed to the promotion of the PI to a tenured associate professor, supported four graduate students (two M. S. and two Ph.D.), and enhanced the education of more than 20 student participants (a mix of graduate and undergraduate). Surveys given to these students reveal that participation in the project (for periods as short as one week) improved their skills at forecasting and safely observing severe weather, and expanded their career aspirations.
